Description: Cypriot terracotta figure of monkey, squatting and holding chin with left hand. Large fragment, missing top of head, part of left arm and leg. Handmade and hollow. Was attached to a sloping object, possibly a closed vessel. Eye, eyebrow and spots painted on in red paint. Pale pink fabric with darker core. Common fine white and black inclusions (<1mm), sparse vesicles.
Curator's comments: Monkey figurines appear in the 6th century BC and use through the Cypro-Archaic II period (600-475BC, Karageorghis 1996). There is a similar, but cruder example from Ormidhia (Karageorghis 1996, pl.9.1, 19-20 fig.15, Type E(b)8). This is more naturalistic than the Karageorghis examples, so is probably from the end of that period. Karageorghis, V. 1996. The coroplastic art of ancient Cyprus. VI. The Cypro-Archaic Period monsters, animals and miscellanea. Nicosia, University of Cyprus.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (B331)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DA.078) (Phase 1)
